comments.commentBody:
A poll like this is the kind of malpractice that brings polling into disrepute. And it's also malpractice by those media that reported it as if it had any news value.

Anyone with half a brain could have predicted how this poll would come out; committed Republicans would unite in naming President Obama as the worst, while Democrats would spread their choices among number of different candidates.

President Obama is to hard-core Republicans what Goldstein was to Big Brother's party faithful; Quinnipiac simply gave them the opportunity for one more hate session.
He was lucky, actually, it could be worse. No the end of the world, only the end of the World Cup for him. Sad enough for Neymar and Brazil!
Not the end of the world, but still, it is the end of the tournament for Neymar. This is the point the article is trying to make.
Do you play football (you say soccer, but it's wrong wording)? Did you ever? Did you ever play professional sports? It's MUCH different, dear jzzy55.

A vertebral facture is not necessarily the end of the world. It depends on the type, location and severity of the fracture.  I had one five years ago from falling down some stairs that was never diagnosed. I was uncomfortable for about six weeks. With some chiropractic help, I kept exercising and working, and it got better. Only bothers me now if I stand for too long. And I'm a 60 year old woman.

Agreed. The World Cup is diminished by Neymar's absence. It is also diminished by thuggish tackling (too many to mention), cynical flopping (Arjen Robben and a host of others), and extremely poor officiating (I hope Velasco Carballo enjoyed the game as a spectator, because he certainly wasn't a referee).

Apparently "the beautiful game" is dead -- as a naive American (as so many Euros like to point out), I'm beginning to believe it never truly existed. But the ugly game is very much alive and well.
The referee should have taken control of the game sooner and now we are all deprived of Neymar and his inspirational touches. The World Cup is diminished by his absence.

I'm a little disappointed in how neutrally parts of this article were worded. Neymar didn't injure his own back, Zuniga broke Neymar's vertebra. It may not have been intentional, but still. It really sounds like poor Neymar threw his back out on his own in the middle of the field or something.
In my opinion the final game will be Brazil x Belgium. I hope so. Let us see.

What would that group still need and want from the rest of Chile? Remember that can't be one-sided, an autonomous entity must pay its own way, give fairly for what it needs and wants.

Asserting the "right" to something may not be a good idea for those involved, even if it is a right. This is the problem for many others too, not just this one example.
Obama brokered what was politically possible, given the GOP opposition which still lives in the 1850's.

Bill, I hear that a lot, and I would like to believe that, but the record shows that both health reform and the stimulus were passed with few or no Republican votes.

I think if Obama had abandoned his fruitless policy of trying to compromise with fanatics, we would be a lot better off.
And don't forget Reagan undermined Carter by making a behind the scenes deal with Iran to release the U.S. prisoners they held on the day Reagan was sworn in -after he was sworn in.

I criticize President Obama quite frequently, but--to coin a phrase from his immediate predecessor-- I think that the American public has "mis-underestimated" him.

To my mind, George W. Bush (despite his coining of the genius phrase "mis-underestimated") ranks as by far the worst president since World War II. Considerably outperforming Bush 43, but still weaker than Obama is Jimmy Carter, for whom little went right.

Obama's legacy will rest on the fortunes of the Affordable Care Act. If it becomes popular, his legacy is assured. I still think, though, that Obama missed a massive opportunity to restore prosperity and to undertake financial reforms in 2009. Had his administration brokered a more progressive economic policy, the economy would have improved more rapidly and set the stage for health care reform.

A woman? Who, Hillary? She of the failed book tour and daily gaffes? Based upon Hillary's track record as SOS convince me why she should be POTUS? I'm all ears.

Oprah would be better qualified. At least Oprah has succeeded at something.
I disagree. The chances of a woman being elected president or even carried in as a vp have the same odds of that occurring in Iran.

Gotta love the word games played by pollsters who choose the wording for a limited number of available responses. There's a good possibility that we will soon elect a woman to lead the country. Just imagine how that changes the polling game and the kind of headlines that could be set up.

@ Richard — Well-taken observations. Just one copy-editing note: I believe the Latin phrase for "bread and circuses [or 'games']" as Juvenal wrote it may have "panem et circenses" (from "Satire X," circa A.D. 100).

"Pānem" is the accusative singular of the noun meaning "bread"; I haven't been able to find any word spelled simply "pan" in Latin.

— Brian

Yes Anetliner, you and I play the same record over and over again, but it must be done. Grid security and fully functioning distribution system are essential for a future USA. So too is the question of vulnerability. I have just returned to Sweden from my month in the northeast, mostly Vermont and a few days at a private home in Albany, NY.

The extraordinary tangle of overhead power lines visible everywhere never fails to amaze me when I first arrive from a city where everything is underground, even quite far out into rural areas now undergoing development. What also intrigues me is that these horrible affronts to vision and views are readily accepted in contrast to the absolute rejection of wind turbines that I see as art objects.

More spending on infrastructure is such an obvious need that one should not need to play the broken record to get the political establishment to act. But what else can we do?

I'm all for the radio device cited in the article, and I believe that I have had the same or a similar device installed, courtesy of my electrical utility. Grid security and distributed power generation are tremendously important issues for the coming years.

At the same time, the grid is also vulnerable due to antiquated infrastructure. Here in the Washington, DC area, overhead power lines fail frequently during storms-- the most recent of which occurred on July 3. Burying the lines is tremendously expensive, but would pay off by reducing maintenance cost and risk over decades.

We need substantially more spending on basic infrastructure.

I think you misread the argument. It is a choice for each nation between its perceived security concerns and its actual economic concerns. Security concerns in a unified South Asia will not be frozen at the point it is today.

A real meaningful compromise is essential to this end goal, no doubt. However, no compromise cannot be achieved through a fundamentalist stand by communities who insist on exclusivity that can only be achieved by expelling others who do not fit in. The geo-political realities here are complicated, and no easy reading can be made in favour of one or another nation.

"the region can either return to the 1990s (with Pakistan’s policy of “strategic depth” undermining what little central authority exists in Afghanistan) or it can pursue commercial corridors"

If it is either or, either Pakistan trades off its security from India or others don't get this economic benefit, then the others won't get it. This can't be done at the expense of any one nation's security, not Pakistan, and not any of the others.

Likewise, Kashmir issues can't be made to go away by India keeps what it has and everyone stops complaining about it.

There are ways to do this. It would be a big benefit for everyone. It just can't be done at the expense of one swurrenders for the benefit of all.

How about India gives Pakistan strategic depth in Afghanistan and gives independence to Kashmir? That too would permit this deal, but entirely at the expense of India instead of entirely as India wants things.

Or then again, a peace deal could compromise -- real, meaningful compromise.

Dr. Virga, please write a book about your animal experiences. Many would be entranced. After just this short article, I will forever be changed when I visit a zoo.

I am a firm believer that animals have emotions. When one of our beloved dogs died, his best buddy did indeed grieve. Ranger used to like to lie under our deck. After his death, his best buddy Baron went out each morning and looked for him under the deck. When he did not find him, he would go out into the yard, lie down, and put his head down. We tried to console him to no avail. Our other dogs tried as well. They sensed it. This went on for a year. It broke our hearts. Finally he stopped looking for Ranger, but he never really was the same dog.

Dream on, Kevin.  Should Hillary Clinton be elected to the Presidency, she will be every bit as much a target for hatred by the Republicans.  The only difference will be that their political hostility will be driven by their sexism rather than their racism.
Hope you realize that had the referee handed out early yellow cards that many of Brazil's best players would have missed the semi-finals.

Very poor officiating has marred many of the World Cup games.  In this one, the referee did not gain control of the game early on and allowed heavy tackling and fouling which nearly got out of hand at times.  Neymar's injury may have been  avoided if yellow cards had been issued in the opening half.  FIFA must commit to improving its officiating as this sort of sub standard job only leads to injury, frustration and loss of credibility.  A shame that Brazil will be down it's leading offensive player against a strong Germany squad.

Agree so was the columbian goalkeeper when the Brazilian collected yellow card for sticking his body in keepers way as he was trying to kick the ball away. 2 of our guys suffered broken noses, I saw a Swiss players eye get busted open vs France. Soccer is a collision sport,elbows, cleats fly all over the place, more than one stretcher has been used in cup games so far
How an American can claim naiveté on a dark side of a sport? You have hockey. Please think before writing and only on your name.
Neymar and Rodriguez. The officiating was terrible.

Perhaps a little naïveté from some Americans regarding the dark side of soccer can explain the general tone of the article, but it's clear as water, Neymar was the victime of a horrible aggression.
Not only Neymar but soccer, and the whole public watching the world cup are the victim.
